dating.remarks: [Letter from D. Koepplin to Newhouse Galleries, New York, 20.12.1990; Koepplin Archive]

pageContext.description:
Cranach's painting of a classical nymph represents an Italian theme but gives it a moralizing twist. The nymph reclines beside a spring, perhaps a reference to a legendary ancient Roman fountain with which a similar Latin verse was associated. The inscription on this painting, 'I am the nymph of the sacred spring, do not disturb my sleep. I am resting',  may be an allusion to the poem. Her bow and arrows hang from the boughs of a nearby tree, while partridges peck in the foreground and deer graze in the middle distance. However, the nude figure resting her head on the robe of a German court lady contributes another aspect to the idyllic scene by admiring herself beguilingly through lowered eyelids. The painting is intended both as an enticement and a warning to Cranach's sophisticated patrons.
[cda 2020]
